  1. Do people with a wider group of friends (connected through the Internet) have stronger in-group reflexes?
    On twitter.com ↗ 2015 May 12 Mood +2 🙂
    1. …in reply to @NelsonPecora
      I have a dumb theory: people who grew up among a small group of people more easily see new people as part of their in-group…
      Permalink On twitter.com ↗ 2015 May 12 Mood -3 🙁
      1. …in reply to @NelsonPecora
        …and thus empathize more when terrible things happen. People who live in cities / have global networks develop quick relevancy reflexes…
        Permalink On twitter.com ↗ 2015 May 12 Mood -3 🙁
        1. …in reply to @NelsonPecora
          …such as ignoring crazy hobos on the subway, but those get inadvertently triggered when tragedy strikes.
          Permalink On twitter.com ↗ 2015 May 12 Mood -7 🙁
          1. …in reply to @NelsonPecora
            It’s callousness, but all humans are callous. The difference is that victims are more quickly sorted into “irrelevant/out-group”
            Permalink On twitter.com ↗ 2015 May 13 Mood -3 🙁
            1. …in reply to @NelsonPecora
              Anyway, humans are terrible at emotions and I’m going to bed. 💤
              Permalink On twitter.com ↗ 2015 May 13 Mood -2 🙁
